syllabus_info.title: Cambridge International AS & A Level Mathematics

learning_objectives.description: identify the forces acting in a given situation
learning_objectives.notes_and_examples: e.g. by drawing a force diagram.

learning_objectives.description: understand the vector nature of force, and find and use components and resultants
learning_objectives.notes_and_examples: Calculations are always required, not approximate solutions by scale drawing.

learning_objectives.description: use the principle that, when a particle is in equilibrium, the vector sum of the forces acting is zero, or equivalently, that the sum of the components in any direction is zero
learning_objectives.notes_and_examples: Solutions by resolving are usually expected, but equivalent methods (e.g. triangle of forces, Lami's Theorem, where suitable) are also acceptable; these other methods are not required knowledge, and will not be referred to in questions.

learning_objectives.description: understand that a contact force between two surfaces can be represented by two components, the normal component and the frictional component
use the model of a 'smooth' contact, and understand the limitations of this model
understand the concepts of limiting friction and limiting equilibrium, recall the definition of coefficient of friction, and use the relationship F = μR or F < μR, as appropriate
learning_objectives.notes_and_examples: Terminology such as 'about to slip' may be used to mean 'in limiting equilibrium' in questions.
e.g. the force exerted by a particle on the ground is equal and opposite to the force exerted by the ground on the particle.
